title: Curriculum Vitae: A Volume of Autobiography
author: Spark, Muriel
snippet: In the new introduction is a long portion of my journal entry describing my visit, his marvellous conversation, and especially his personal reminiscences of Swinburne.

title: Curriculum Vitae: A Volume of Autobiography
author: Spark, Muriel
snippet: Nineteenth-and twentieth-century poets were my preference – Wordsworth, Browning, Tennyson, Swinburne, and what were known as the Georgian poets (we were in the reign of George V): Edmund Blunden, Rupert Brooke, Walter de la Mare, Yeats, John Masefield, Robert Bridges, and, the only woman among them, Alice Meynell.

title: The living age ...
snippet: There is no vagueness or hesitancy atthe back of his judgments, which areexpressed with the same uncompromising clearness, whether he undertakesto show the vanity of the term "experimental romance," as applied to thework of Zola; or to hit off Emerson as"the sage who, in finding wisdom, sometimes lost himself;" or describes himself as bidden by Swinburne to a "banquet where the dishes are all silver andgold, but nothing besides pepper isserved in them;" or whether, whilerendering full justice to the vivifyinginfluence of Walt Whitman, who always refreshed him "like a dash of saltspray," he exposes what he calls the"inverted dandyism" of the open shirtand the athletic muscles.

title: When winter comes to Main street,
author: Overton, Grant Martin
snippet: He is still in the business of publishing,  being one of the principal personages in the ancient and well-tried firm of Chatto & Windus, the English publishers of Swinburne and Mark Twain.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: Iam very much obliged by the offer of so valuable apresent " (this refers to my statuette of the French poet, ofwhich I had offered a copy to Swinburne) "which I shalltreasure on all accounts.

title: Old diaries, 1881-1901 /
author: Gower, Ronald Sutherland
snippet: The post, I write on the nth of March, brought methis morning two remarkable letters, one from Swinburne,the other from Lord Wolseley; the former writes asfollows : —
